docs.abstract: Karen Stabiner article on belief by many experts that lack of parental discipline is at root of many childhood and adolescent behavior problems; photo (M)
docs.snippet: DR. JAMES VARGA, a pediatrician, has been in practice in Santa Monica, Calif., for 21 years, enough time for a generation of well-educated, middle- and upper-middle-class parents to have visited his examination room with their children. His diagnosis...
docs.lead_paragraph: DR. JAMES VARGA, a pediatrician, has been in practice in Santa Monica, Calif., for 21 years, enough time for a generation of well-educated, middle- and upper-middle-class parents to have visited his examination room with their children. His diagnosis of those parents: ''Absolutely too permissive.'' The syndrome, according to Dr. Varga, starts with sleep problems, when the child is 9 to 12 months old. Then comes the tantrums when the child is 2 or 3. By adolescence, it is drugs and alcohol. ''People are not setting limits,'' he said.

headline.main: The Problem With Kids Today? Today's Parents, Some Say

docs.abstract: Elizabeth Yoffe article describes experience of having a stroke; photo (M)
docs.snippet: IT happened again the other night. Somehow, in my sleep, I became aware of an intensifying numbness in my left side. My brain sent a warning signal and I jerked awake with a gasp. My heart pounded, my breathing quickened and my mind flooded with a...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT happened again the other night. Somehow, in my sleep, I became aware of an intensifying numbness in my left side. My brain sent a warning signal and I jerked awake with a gasp. My heart pounded, my breathing quickened and my mind flooded with a familiar panic: ''Is this it? Is it happening again?'' It's been 10 years since the stroke. One minute I was sitting at the breakfast table drinking coffee and the next I lost all connection to my left hand. It was beyond numb -- as though the hand had simply vanished.

docs.abstract: Ovarian cancer is often called the silent killer because it is difficult to detect, but research money is at an all-time high; National Cancer Insitute initiative and other research efforts promise advances in early testing; early warning signs of disease described; photo (M)
docs.snippet: OVARIAN cancer has been nicknamed the silent killer because it is difficult to detect. When found, it has often spread beyond the ovaries and is too advanced to cure. Even the symptoms are vague and easily ignored: who hasn't felt bloated and tired...
docs.lead_paragraph: OVARIAN cancer has been nicknamed the silent killer because it is difficult to detect. When found, it has often spread beyond the ovaries and is too advanced to cure. Even the symptoms are vague and easily ignored: who hasn't felt bloated and tired from time to time? But experts in the field say that a new National Cancer Institute initiative, the Ovarian Cancer Early Detection Program, promises to yield more sensitive, highly specific -- and thus accurate -- screening tests for ovarian cancer within the next five years. The program, which unites 26 comprehensive cancer centers in the United States along with more than 100 scientists worldwide, is planning to enroll more than 10,000 asymptomatic women to develop new means for accurately detecting early-stage cancer.

headline.main: Researchers Fix Their Sights on an Elusive Silent Killer

docs.abstract: Preliminary tests show drug compound Altropane may be useful in early detection of Parkinson's disease; Altropane's usefulness is as imaging agent in scanning with single photon emission computed tomography, a technique that is less expensive than currently used positron emission tomography (PET) scanning; photos (M)
docs.snippet: PARKINSON'S disease, which affects about one million Americans, is a progressive, incurable illness in which the death of brain cells leads to loss of muscle control, paralysis and, in the worst cases, death. It is usually diagnosed with a PET scan,...
docs.lead_paragraph: PARKINSON'S disease, which affects about one million Americans, is a progressive, incurable illness in which the death of brain cells leads to loss of muscle control, paralysis and, in the worst cases, death. It is usually diagnosed with a PET scan, but the positron emission tomography machines that do the scans are expensive, and only a handful exist in American hospitals. Now scientists are testing a compound that they say will make it possible to detect the abnormality that leads to Parkinson's far earlier in its development. The compound, Altropane, is in the final stages of clinical testing required by the Food and Drug Administration, and is expected to be available next year, according to Boston Life Sciences Inc., which is marketing it.

docs.abstract: Anne Raver article on apparent healing power of gardens, which are becoming more frequent feature of hospitals and nursing homes; photos (M)
docs.snippet: IT was a sunny day in the garden at the Pleasant Bay Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Brewster, Mass. So sunny that Kaleigh, a yellow Labrador, would not leave the shade of his favorite zelkova tree, where he kept an eye on his human, Bill Ellis,...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT was a sunny day in the garden at the Pleasant Bay Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Brewster, Mass. So sunny that Kaleigh, a yellow Labrador, would not leave the shade of his favorite zelkova tree, where he kept an eye on his human, Bill Ellis, 69, reading in a wheelchair. Mr. Ellis, a former manufacturing executive from Wisconsin, found out he had Parkinson's disease six years ago, and has been a resident of the center for more than a year. His wife, Pam, visits daily, along with Kaleigh. The garden, they have found, is a cheerful place to congregate. Just off the dining room, it is nestled in the northwest corner of the X-shaped complex. The triangular space measures about 5,000 square feet, with views of pines and sky to the west. ''When it's nice, we have our lunch and dinner out here,'' Mrs. Ellis said.

headline.main: Gardens That Harness Nature's Healing Powers

docs.abstract: Efforts by California Council of the Blind has over the past year led to installation of several dozen automated teller machines that provide spoken instructions for the blind; now, National Federation of the Blind has launched federal lawsuit to make talking teller machines more widely available (S)
docs.snippet: FOR the estimated 1.1 million Americans who are legally blind, using an automated teller machine can be an exercise in frustration.    While many teller machines have Braille keys and labels, most blind people do not read Braille. Even for those who...
docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the estimated 1.1 million Americans who are legally blind, using an automated teller machine can be an exercise in frustration. While many teller machines have Braille keys and labels, most blind people do not read Braille. Even for those who do, advocates for the blind say that the Braille-equipped machines are next to useless because they require the user to follow a sequence of visual instructions on a screen.

docs.abstract: *Women are becoming increasingly familiar with challenge, and agony, of medical decision making; revolution in patients' rights and explosion of information on Internet and elsewhere is enabling women to educate themselves as never before; doctors' attitudes have changed as well; once derided for their paternalism, many now expect patients to research their own diseases and make decisions on their own; studies show that women are gatekeepers of family health, making decisions not only for themselves, but also for their spouses, children and parents; photos (M)
docs.snippet: SUSAN HOROWITZ faced the classic patient's dilemma. Three different doctors had given her three different recommendations about whether to undergo chemotherapy for her breast cancer. ''I found the idea of chemo really frightening,'' she recalled....
docs.lead_paragraph: SUSAN HOROWITZ faced the classic patient's dilemma. Three different doctors had given her three different recommendations about whether to undergo chemotherapy for her breast cancer. ''I found the idea of chemo really frightening,'' she recalled. Chemotherapy, she knew, would throw her into menopause - and she was only 45 years old.

headline.main: The Big Decisions? They're All Yours

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE
keywords.name: subject

docs.abstract: Some 13 million Americans suffer from thyroid disorders, most of them women, but more than half do not know it; thyroid disorders are widely undiagnosed and misdiagnosed because symptoms can be ambiguous and doctors do not make simple blood test, particularly under managed care; photo (M)
docs.snippet: SOME 13 million Americans suffer from thyroid disorders, most of them women, including Barbara Bush, Tipper Gore and the Olympic track star Gail Devers. But more than half don't know it.    Thyroid disorders, experts say,  are among the most...
docs.lead_paragraph: SOME 13 million Americans suffer from thyroid disorders, most of them women, including Barbara Bush, Tipper Gore and the Olympic track star Gail Devers. But more than half don't know it. Thyroid disorders, experts say, are among the most undiagnosed and misdiagnosed problems in the United States. Doctors generally don't examine the thyroid. Disorders come on slowly, and the symptoms can be ambiguous.

headline.main: Your Thyroid May Be Talking, but Is the Doctor Listening?

docs.abstract: New research suggests that concerns that children who suffer from repeated middle-ear infections are at high risk of developing speech and language problems are overblown, if not groundless; Dr Jack L Paradise of Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh, lead author of study reported in journal Pediatrics, comments (M)
docs.snippet: PARENTS and doctors have long assumed that young children who suffer from repeated middle-ear infections are at high risk of developing speech and language problems. But new research suggests that such concerns are overblown, if not groundless - that...
docs.lead_paragraph: PARENTS and doctors have long assumed that young children who suffer from repeated middle-ear infections are at high risk of developing speech and language problems. But new research suggests that such concerns are overblown, if not groundless - that there is little or no association between the number and severity of ear infections in the first three years of life and language abilities in preschool and beyond.

headline.main: When a Young Ear Gets an Infection

docs.abstract: Growing field of research is struggling to explain a persistent racial gap in US infant mortality rates; even as overall rate improves, to a record low national average of 7.2 deaths per 1,000 live births, the disparity between whites and blacks has grown, from 2 to nearly 2.4 times the number of infant deaths; especially troubling is evidence that this is not simply because of poverty; photos (M)
docs.snippet: ETHELYN BOWERS had a master's degree, an executive-level job and a husband who was a doctor with access to some of the best medical care available. But her accomplishments and connections seemed to make little difference when she endured the...
docs.lead_paragraph: ETHELYN BOWERS had a master's degree, an executive-level job and a husband who was a doctor with access to some of the best medical care available. But her accomplishments and connections seemed to make little difference when she endured the premature births and subsequent deaths of three babies, two of whom were in a set of triplets. A competitive businesswoman who is immersed in her career and the hectic schedules of her surviving children, now 9 and 11, Ms. Bowers is candid about her losses but does not dwell on their possible causes. ''I just chalked it up to bad luck, mainly,'' said Ms. Bowers, a sales director for Lucent Technologies who lives with her family in Livingston, N.J.

headline.main: A Racial Gap in Infant Deaths, and a Search for Reasons
